Operating Systems Documentation

Project 2: Threads
Greg Patterson - grpatter@indiana.edu
Eric Spencer - erspence@indiana.edu
Indiana University Fall 2009


Objectives:
To demonstrate the proper use of synchronization primitives.
To solve synchronization problems both on paper and in software.
To understand how system calls affect thread scheduling in the operating system.
To demonstrate an understanding of how to use the POSIX Threads library.
To develop skills in testing and debugging threaded code.
To demonstrate and develop your C programming skills.
To develop defensive programming techniques.
To develop critical software development strategies (i.e., documentation, testing).

Part 1: The Dining Philosophers Problem
In this part of the assignment you will be implementing two solutions to the Dining Philoso- phers Problem. You will implement the solution in Figure 6.15 in the text which is not deadlock free. Additionally you will implement another solution that is deadlock free. This pseudo code is taken from the second edition of \Operating Systems: Design and Implementation" by Tanenbaum and Woodhull (1997).

Part 2: Work Pool Problem
Overview
In this problem, there is a pool of work to be done, and we have a pool of threads to use to do it. The pool of work should be drawn from using a first in first out policy (it is a queue). Furthermore, the workers require exclusive access to shared resources to complete the tasks - the resources that are needed are task dependent. Each task takes a certian amount of time, at which point the worker can proceed to a new task. New work enters the queue at random intervals. If the queue is empty, workers should wait briely, then check for more work.

Make File Instructions


all: philDeadlock philNoDeadlock workers
philDeadlock: philDeadlock.cpp
philNoDeadlock: philNoDeadlock.cpp
workers: workers.cpp
clean: removes all files except source
